Several years ago I was involved in a case in which a deceased woman was found in her home surrounded by empty pill bottles. The initial on scene officer thought it must be a suicide.  Malice is that state of mind which results in the intentional doing of a wrongful act to another without legal excuse or justification, at a time when the mind of the actor is under the control of reason. Malice may result from any unlawful or unjustifiable motive including anger, hatred or revenge....
 
 But the instruction also goes on to read, in relevant part:
 
 Heat of passion excludes malice when that heat of passion arises from provocation that reasonably produces an emotional state of mind such as...terror or fear....
 
 Based upon what we know, his actions reasonably would have created a state of mind causing the woman to act out of terror or fear. That is a classic case of heat of passion.
